text: Dialogue between Maiden and Her Beloved

I \add am\add* a rose\f + \fr 2:1 \ft More likely “meadow saffron” or “crocus.” Hebrew scholars and botanists suggest the term refers to \fqa Ashodelos \ft (lily family), \fqa Narcissus tazetta \ft (narcissus or daffodil), or \fqa Colchicum autumnale \ft (meadow saffron or crocus) (e.g., \xt Isa 35:1 \ft ). The location of this flower in Sharon suggests a common wild flower rather than a rose. The maiden compares herself to a simple, common flower of the field \f* of Sharon,
a lily of the valleys.
Like a lily among the thorns,\f + \fr 2:2 \ft Or “brambles” \f*
so \add is\add* my love among the maidens.
As an apple tree among the trees of the forest,
so \add is\add* my beloved among the young men.
In his shade ⸤I sat down with delight⸥,\f + \fr 2:3 \ft Literally “I sat down and I delighted” \f*
and his fruit \add was\add* sweet to my palate.
Banquet Hall of Love
He brought me to the house of the wine,
and his intention \add was\add* love toward me.
Sustain me with the raisins,
refresh me with the apples,
⸤for I \add am\add* lovesick⸥.\f + \fr 2:5 \ft Literally “for I myself \fq am \ft sick with love” \f*
Double Refrain: Embrace and Adjuration
His left \add hand\add* \add is\add* under my head,
and his right \add hand\add* embraces\f + \fr 2:6 \ft Or “would embrace me” \f* me.
I adjure you, ⸤O maidens of Jerusalem⸥,\f + \fr 2:7 \ft Literally “O daughters of Jerusalem” \f*
by the gazelles or by the does of the field,

do not arouse or awaken love until it pleases!\f + \fr 2:7 \ft Or “Do not stir up or awaken the love until it is willing,” or “Do not disturb or interrupt \fq our \ft lovemaking until it is satisfied” \f*
Rendezvous in the Countryside
The voice of my beloved!
Look! Here ⸤he⸥\f + \fr 2:8 \ft Literally “this one” \f* comes leaping upon the mountains,
bounding over the hills!
My beloved is like a gazelle or ⸤a young stag⸥.\f + \fr 2:9 \ft Literally “the fawn of the stag” \f*
Look! ⸤He is⸥\f + \fr 2:9 \ft Literally “This \fq is he \ft ” \f* standing behind our wall,
gazing ⸤through⸥\f + \fr 2:9 \ft Literally “from” \f* the window,
looking ⸤through⸥\f + \fr 2:9 \ft Literally “from” \f* the lattice.
My beloved answered and said to me,
“⸤Arise⸥,\f + \fr 2:10 \ft Literally “Arise, you” \f* my beloved! ⸤Come, my beauty⸥!\f + \fr 2:10 \ft Literally “And come, you” \f*
For look! The winter is over;
⸤the rainy season⸥\f + \fr 2:11 \ft Literally “the rain” \f* ⸤has turned and gone away⸥.\f + \fr 2:11 \ft Literally “is over; it is gone” \f*
The blossoms ⸤appear⸥\f + \fr 2:12 \ft Literally “is seen” \f* ⸤in the land⸥;\f + \fr 2:12 \ft Literally “on the earth” \f*

⸤the time of singing\f + \fr 2:12 \ft Most likely, a subtle word play occurs here since there are two different words in Hebrew spelled the same way: “pruning” and “singing.” The former plays upon the first line and the latter upon the third line \f* has arrived⸥;\f + \fr 2:12 \ft Literally “the time of the song arrived” \f*
the voice of the turtledove is heard in our land.
The fig tree puts forth her figs,
and the vines \add are in\add* blossom; they give fragrance.
⸤Arise⸥,\f + \fr 2:13 \ft Literally “Arise, to you!” \f* my beloved! ⸤Come, my beauty⸥!”\f + \fr 2:13 \ft Literally “My beauty, come, you” \f*
My dove, in the clefts of the rock,

⸤in the secluded place⸥\f + \fr 2:14 \ft Literally “in the secret place” \f*\f + \fr 2:14 \ft Or “in the covering” \f* ⸤in the mountain⸥,\f + \fr 2:14 \ft Literally “foothold in the rock” \f*\f + \fr 2:14 \ft Or “cliff” \f*
Let me see your face,
let me hear your voice;
for your voice \add is\add* sweet and your face \add is\add* lovely.
Catch for us the foxes,
the little foxes destroying vineyards,
for\f + \fr 2:15 \ft Or “while” \f* our vineyards \add are in\add* blossom!
Poetic Refrain(s)
⸤My beloved belongs to me and I belong to him⸥;\f + \fr 2:16 \ft Literally “My beloved for me and I for him” \f*
he pastures his flock among the lilies.
Until the day breathes and the shadows flee,
turn, my beloved!

⸤Be like⸥\f + \fr 2:17 \ft Literally “Be like for you” \f* a gazelle\f + \fr 2:17 \ft Or “a buck gazelle” \f* or ⸤young stag⸥\f + \fr 2:17 \ft Literally “the fawn of the stag” \f* on the cleft mountains.\f + \fr 2:17 \ft Or “the mountains of Bether” \f*
